Award.AwardTitle: inter Science of Learning Center Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:

This proposal requests funds to support the eighth annual Inter-Science of Learning Centers (i-SLC) Conference, organized by the graduate students and postdoctoral fellows of the 6 Science of Learning Centers (SLCs). This event has served as a vital venue for exchanging research findings across the SLCs, sharing resources and stimulating career development opportunities for Center trainees. This highly productive activity has resulted in cross-center collaborations, including cross-center student exchanges for additional training in other laboratories.

This year, the conference will be hosted by the NSF-funded Temporal Dynamics of Learning Center (TDLC) in San Diego, CA on May 31-June 2, 2015. The theme is "Research and Innovation: the intersection with Education ". Requested funds will be used to pay for conference facilities at the University of California San Diego (UCSD) and to cover participants' costs of attending, including travel and per diem.

The 2015 Conference will build upon the previous Conferences to facilitate intra-center and cross-Center collaborative through oral/signed presentations in symposia and methodology workshops, alumni panels, alumni presentations and the creation of an onllne research network which connects past, present and future SLC trainees.

Broader Impacts

The i-SLC has been instrumental in catalyzing a large and robust network of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who will provide a firm foundation on which the future of Science of Learning will build upon, as it evolves into a full-bodied, interdisciplinary research field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eighth annual inter-Science of Learning Centers (iSLC) Conference was hosted by the NSF-funded Temporal Dynamics of Learning Center (TDLC) in San Diego on May 31st - June 2nd, 2015. Seventy-five trainees from across the six Science of Learning centers attended the conference. The conference, which had the theme “Research and Innovation: The Intersection with Education” had three goals: (1) to support intra-center collaboration, (2) to promote inter-center collaboration, and (3) to improve collaboration with the broader community. To support intra-center collaboration, there were alumni panels and alumni presentations that focused on alumni experiences as new professors and new industry professionals. There was a workshop to facilitate the creation of an online research network which connects past, present, and future SLC trainees. To promote inter-center collaboration, participants gave talks, seminars, and workshops highlighting how research in the SLCs interfaced with educational practice and theory. Finally, to improve collaboration with the broader community, a workshop was hosted in partnership with the Fleet Science Museum and Nan Renner, who directed the NSF funded San Diego’s Art of Science Learning Incubator for Innovation. The workshop emphasized the benefits of conducting Science of Learning research in collaboration with museums and other community-based organizations, and presented relevant strategies for forming such collaborations.

The conference had multiple intellectual merits and broader impacts. The conference gave center trainees the opportunity to share their research and be exposed to new and alternative methodologies, paradigms, and tools used by their peers from across the different Science of Learning centers. The center trainees engaged with our keynote speakers, who focused on Educational Policy and Science Public Engagement, to learn best practices on disseminating research to educators. Participants received training on how to design, evaluate, and do research on museum exhibits, helping them translate their research to the public. These kinds of opportunities will ultimately help to enrich and expand the infrastructure for interdisciplinary research in the Science of Learning.
